subject: control: add command line tool to retrieve fan status (get function)
commitMessage:
control: add command line tool to retrieve fan status (get function)

This is part two of a multipart commit to create a fan-control command
line utility to report service status, show target/actual RPM/PWM info,
and manually control single fans. This commit implements the "get"
command. Further functionality will come in subsequent commits.

Sample output: /tmp/fanctl get
TARGET SENSOR    TARGET(RPM)   FEEDBACK SENSOR   FEEDBACK(RPMS)
===============================================================
fan0_0                 10000            fan0_0            10000
                                        fan0_1            13591
fan1_0                 10000            fan1_0            10000
                                        fan1_1            13591
fan2_0                 10000            fan2_0            10000
                                        fan2_1            13591
fan3_0                 10000            fan3_0            10000
                                        fan3_1            13591
fan4_0                 10000            fan4_0            10000
                                        fan4_1            13591
fan5_0                 10000            fan5_0            10000
                                        fan5_1            13591

Signed-off-by: Mike Capps <mikepcapps@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Matthew Barth <msbarth@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I5a918b34b807fa284c0072db2141aa572ae0f0da

Patch Set 37:

(1 comment)
Could you show example output here?  I'd be interested to see it.
Sample output has been added to the commit message.

See comment in previous commit.  Do we need global variables?

If we need to pass several things around between functions, and it is too complex for parameters, maybe we need a simple data structure to hold them?

Note: I don't know the phosphor-fan-presence repo very well.  If global variables are frequently used there then please ignore this comment.

Normally it's a poor programming practice. However I think an exception can be made when the program is a command-line utility that runs, does one thing, and exits. I'll ACK this and hold off for more input.
Ack
If any of the D-Bus calls fail, they will likely throw an exception.  Do we need a try/catch in main() to catch the exception and print it out vs. just core dumping?
Done

Need to update this to show the two different actions?

Note that CLI supports enums, so you could just define an enum of the valid actions and then have a switch statement vs. if/else if/else.

https://github.com/CLIUtils/CLI11/blob/master/examples/enum.cpp

I'm guessing it would produce decent help text too so you didn't have to remember to update that when new values are added.
Ack
"loadVars" is a pretty vague name.  Maybe loadGlobalVars()?
Done
you already filled in interfaces up above (should probably also make it const so this wouldn't have compiled)
Done
See comments in previous commit re: these two lines.
Done
Same as I mentioned in the prior commit in regard to referencing the script and issue.
Done

Thank you for removing the global variable pathMap.

Global *constants* are no problem, so you didn't need to move those into this function.  But if it made the code simpler that is fine.
Done
The feedbacks will not be in PWM. Currently those will only be given on the Sensor.Value interface's Value property in RPM
Ack
Done
A Romulus system, if you're able to find one, used PWM targets.
Not an option. will have to find another solution. see comment below.

Same comment as above.  Global constants are not a problem and would be preferable if you need the data in multiple functions.  But if this is the only place the data is used, putting it here is fine too.
Done
This should be removed.

Ack

Actually it is used in the final commit.
Looks as though these are only used in this function, so lets remove these and put the strings directly in the method call below. Unless I'm missing something?
ultimately used in set/resume/reload.
Ack
yikes. this comment got out of alignment with the function
fixed in latest commit.
What about a PWM target?
Ack and this is a TODO. Attempts to get a Romulus system failed, will have to set up simics for PWM testing.
Done
Add option "get" ?
Done

Not "Fan control" failed, this script failed right?

Also, should probably set the return code to not be 0 if there's a failure of this script in case users wrap this tool in a script, etc..
Done
You said "Done" to Matt's comment about not mentioning the script and issue, but they are still mentioned here?
Done
Since this conditional is used twice, perhaps it should be converted to a simple one line function so the code is common?
Done

Does this work for PWM now?  If so, the comment should be updated.  Also, if it supports both should it include a unit value?  e.g. does the value 100 mean 100% PWM (max speed) or 100 RPMs (really slow)?
comment fixed. PWM/RPM units are dependent on hw-specific implementation; this utility simply passes through values to/from the driver interface.
Ack
Nit: If the executable is 'fanctl', then this should be lower case to match?
Done
Oh, this probably explains comment in earlier commit. Seems like this was only used once, so not really needed?

I was asked to refactor quite a bit of this code. so constants that once were global were moved to local scope. The refactoring made rebasing older commits quite a rodeo, which is why some fixes are only in later commits.
Perhaps this should be argv[0], in case the binary/application name changes?
Done
Looks like this can also be removed now as well?
Done
What about a mix of RPM and PWM based fans? Maybe we should create an issue on the backlog to track enhancing this tool to be able to support a mix of RPM and PWM controled of fans.

Done

https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/3337
created issue #dev3337
Why the copy? Why not just use what's in "tach"?
Done
Out of curiosity, if this was to throw an exception, what's returned back to the user in the console where they're running the tool?

root@p10bmc:~# /tmp/fanctl get 
TARGET SENSOR    TARGET(RPM)   FEEDBACK SENSOR    FEEDBACK(RPM)
    ===============================================================
    fan0_0/tmp/fanctl failed: DBus method failed: xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon-ef376ae656f95cf4f5f1302e716
    1.Hwmon1 /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/fan_tach/fan0_0 org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties Get

or
root@p10bmc:~# /tmp/fanctl get 
/tmp/fanctl failed: DBus method failed: xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetSubTreePaths
Great, thanks for the info!
